text: (upbeat music)

- So welcome to
"Conversations with Leaders."

I'm Wesley Story. I'm an
enterprise strategist at AWS.
Today, I'm joined with Amy,

and I'd like you to introduce
yourself a little bit, Amy,

'cause I don't wanna take
that from the audience.

And I'd love you to tell me
about your role at Autodesk.

And give me a little
background if you would.
- Great, so I'm Amy Bunszel obviously,
and I'm the executive vice president

of our Architecture,
Engineering, & Construction
design solutions tools.

And so what my team does
is we build software
for people in the AEC industry,
working on everything from roads, bridges,
highways, water infrastructure, stadiums,

pretty much everything
in the built environment.
- Wow, that's a lot. That's a lot.
- It's a lot of fun.
- Yeah, I had no idea that you have
such a massive scope, quite frankly.
So how do you balance all that?

- Well, I have a really
great team working for me.

So I spend most of my time
thinking about the broader

strategic longer-term aspects
of what we're trying to do,
and also with customers.

it's super exciting to
visit our customers.
- So Amy, as a leader, you've talked a lot

about being an innovator
and risk-taker at heart.

However, as you know, sometimes
risk-taking can be risky.
(both laugh)

So tell me a little bit
about how you actually
came up with that leadership style
and what it means to your business.

- So for me, risk isn't
about being reckless.

It's about really
thinking about innovation
and exploration and experimentation,
and really thinking about different ways
to try to learn and develop.

And so I find that if we are
open to the experimentation

and we're thinking about what
our outcomes are gonna be,
and if we're not hitting them,
then it's a matter of just reorienting.

So it's not about taking a
risk that's so big, you know,
you're gonna put the company at risk
or a team or a product at risk.

But it's really about
taking the kind of risks

that you can learn from
and then build upon
as you go forward.

- You know, one thing I run
into with some customers,

especially those that
wanna emulate this whole

technology industry thing
of failing fast, right,

is culture, and how do
you create that culture
where failure feels safe for people?

And also, if I can add
this one more thing,

because of your industry,
you might relate to this,

is some industries feel like
failure is not an option,
like it's an evil thing.

Tell me a little bit
about how you've created
that culture that makes that okay.

- It's an interesting thing,
and it's changed over the years

for me because I think
seven or eight years ago,
there was this whole fail fast,

and as leaders, we're
like, it's okay to fail.
And my team would be looking at me
like I was a crazy person.

'Cause we wakes up in the
morning thinking I'm gonna fail?
You know, you got a bunch of A-players,

people really excited
about what they're doing,

and you're telling them
that they should fail.

So we've kind of moved
away from that language,
and we talk more about experimentation.

So again, it's about
giving people the freedom
to go and explore something,

but also having expected
outcomes, so you know, all right,

we tried this, we were
hoping this would happen.

It didn't happen. We learned
this, so we're gonna stop now.
- So Amy, Autodesk has sustainability
as a corporate imperative.

And I imagine it shows up
in lots of different ways,
from how you guys think about products
to how you run your business.
Can you tell me a little bit about that?

- Absolutely, so yes, as a
company, we're carbon neutral,
we are doing all of the important things
that companies do in that space.

But I think more importantly,
the impact we can have

with our customers and helping
them achieve more sustainable

and resilient outcomes is
really where we're different
from a lot of other companies.

We've been talking about
sustainability for far more

than 10 years, before it was
fashionable to talk about.
And what's interesting with our products
is we help customers really reduce carbon,

create more resilient
buildings, lightweight things

so they're easier to
ship around the world.

There's just a whole
lot of positive outcomes
that we can help deliver.
And we have a couple key initiatives.
One is around total carbon.

So more and more these
days, people are realizing

it's not just the air conditioners
and the heating systems

that contributes to the
carbon in a building.
It's all of the materials you chose
to build that building with,

and how far did they come
to get to the building?
That's really called embodied carbon.

And then there's this thing
called operating carbon.

And so the built environment
contributes the most

to greenhouse gases of
anything, any producer at all.

So we're really partnering
up with our customers to try

to figure out how we can build
more sustainable buildings.
- Is there a lesson you've learned

to keeping sustainability
front and center?
- You know, it's interesting.

It has to really be, it's
also good for business.

That's really the-
- Tell me more.

- When it was just, you know,
I think there was a time

where people felt
sustainability was just there
to tick a box and make people feel good.
But really it's good for business,
and it's good for the planet.
I think a good example is we look

at building product manufacturers
and people that provide

all the concrete, drywall,
things for buildings.

These days, architects and
owners are choosing suppliers
based on how green they are.

So if you're ignoring that,
you're not gonna be selected.

But if you're delivering
25% less carbon emissions

than the person down the road,
you're gonna get selected

to have your materials
leveraged in that project.
So that's real.
- So when thinking about product strategy,
how does sustainability influence
how your team approaches it?

- So it all kind of goes
back to the customer

and what customer problems
are we trying to solve?

What outcomes are we trying
to help them deliver?
And so these days, carbon's a big deal,

but some of the other items
that are really important
is on the other end of the life cycle
is operating the building or the facility.

And so we've been hearing
a lot from customers

that they would like to
adopt some of the kind of
manufacturing practices with digital twins
into the building space.

And so we're working
with them to figure out

how we can help them operate
better and save money

and use less resources
on that side of things.
- Tell me more about that.
That's something I get the chance
to talk to a lot of customers about,

but everyone might not
fully understand what it is.

So could you first start
with what is a digital twin?
- So a digital twin is effectively

a digital representation
of a physical thing.
So it could be anything from a, you know,
it could be a simple Excel spreadsheet

that sort of has all
the parameters you need
for your physical object,

or it could be a full-on
three-dimensional model
of a building connected up to sensors

that tell you how hot
is it in the building,
where are the people in the building,

are these conference
rooms utilized very often?
All kinds of information that you'd get

off of sensors as well,
all of this put together

in a visual representation so
that you can do things like

predictive maintenance,
renovations, optimizations,

really to drive the most
efficient and effective spaces.

- So a virtual representation
of the physical something

or entity, if you will, and
it sounds like lots of data.
And my favorite thing about data
is when you put it to action.

So you started to allude
to that, but what are some

of the other things you can do
to put this data into action?

- So you can definitely drive
a lot of insights out of that.
And you might be wanting to figure out
how to configure a space for, you know,

maybe you have underutilized
areas of your facility

and you don't know why, so
you can actually play around
with reconfiguring it in different ways,
and then watch the traffic
and see how the utilization might change.

And that in turn might
inform your next project

where you might be making
different decisions
about how you use the space.
- So it's being able to sense and respond

to different external factors
and predicting outcomes

and also making these automatic
or autonomous decisions?

- Yep.
- Is that something

you're seeing as well?
- Yes, it is.
In particular, 'cause they're operating

large-scale facilities,
even if you were to think
of like a hospital, for example,

and understanding all of
the different componentry,
equipment in there, and like how often
does it need to be refreshed?
Do you have it on order?

Is it a critical piece
of equipment that might
be ready to fail, do you have a backup?
All these things can be planned en masse,
like on hundreds of facilities.

So it's not the sort of bespoke
labor of a manual operation.

It really can be done
at scale quite broadly.
- So when considering digital twins,

and all the vast amounts
of data that comes

from digital twins, or
actually supports them rather,

some of the problems that
some companies run into

is how do you actually
manage all this data?

How do you manage it from
a technical perspective,
but let's not worry about that yet.

Let's worry about the
nontechnical executives.

What do you recommend to
them when you think about

how you organize around it,
how you actually get analytics
and insights out of it?

What are some insights and
thoughts you have there?
- So the most successful ways
we've seen people start is with a pilot.

Thinking about either
a particular facility
or a particular aspect of that facility,

and then trying to
understand, what is something

that they wish they can
drive as an outcome?
And then it's a matter of,

let's just look for the data
that supports that use case.

And so you break it down
so that you can build

a cross-functional team that
can then work together on this.
And then once you have success there,

you can find another challenge
and another challenge.

So you don't open it up
and try to do everything

all at once.
- Don't boil the ocean.

- Yeah.
- Yes.

So you probably won't
be surprised at this,

but I still run into a
lot of companies that say
we gotta build a data lake.
And the first thing I ask them is, why?
Like, what are you trying to solve for?

And I think the same lesson
is applied there as well
is start with your insights.

Start with what are the
problems we're trying to solve,

what are the use cases,
or in Amazonian speak,
we like to work backwards
from customer outcomes or problems.
And I think that's a lesson that we all
need to kind of take heed to, right?
- Yes, well, and also, you will find out
you don't have all the data that you want.

You have too much data
that you're not using,

but then you might be
missing a key piece of data
that you need to figure out how to go get.
And that in itself is a big key learning.

- So Amy, you guys have had
a pretty big acquisition.
Can you tell me a little bit about that
and what they do and what's behind it?

- Absolutely, we did our first
billion-dollar acquisition,

which my team drove, and
that was really exciting,
as you can imagine.
And we acquired a company called Innovyze.

And Innovyze builds
software that does design
of water systems and also digital twins
for water ecosystems.

So what an amazing time
to be working in water.
It's such an important and vital resource,

and there's just so much work
happening around the globe

to fix problems and create
opportunities for people

in terms of how they
get their water supply.
- That sounds like a massive undertaking,
not just the acquisition,
but the mission of the business itself.

- Yeah, the mission of the
business was very exciting for us

'cause it very much aligns
to really our core values
and areas that we were working in already.
But by buying Innovyze, we connect that

to the Autodesk portfolio,
we really have an end-to-end
solution for water now.

So the two companies together,
there was almost no overlap

in what we were doing, so
we're really coming to market
with an incredibly strong story.

- And it's also an applied
example of like digital twin

in a specific industry that
has a meaningful outcome.

- It's a great example
of modernization, too.

So a lot of the digitization
that needs to happen
is in a lot of these water municipalities.

There's just a lot of
aging infrastructure there,
and real opportunities to make an impact
on less water lost in systems

and delivering better
experiences for everyone.

- And I think water is something
that we can all relate to
'cause we all need it, right?

It's such a critical resource
that has lots of shortages
or all kind of other issues in the world.
But you mentioned that our infrastructure,

even the United States, is
older than people might think.

So if you wire that up, it
gives you tremendous insights.

- Right?
- It does, 'cause you can

identify in advance where
you might have problems,
do maintenance in advance of problems.

And if you think about,
an example I like to use
is you're driving down the street,
there's a sinkhole in your neighborhood,

and all of the utility trucks
and everyone else is there.

Oftentimes that's 'cause
there was an undetected leak
that went on for a long period of time.

And when they finally
realized it, it was, you know,
very, very, very severe.

Whereas with things like
digital twins for water,

you can identify these problems
when they're tiny problems

and get in and address them
before they become big problems.

- That's tangible impact.
- Mm-hmm. It is.
- Kudos to you and the team on that.
- Oh, thank you.

- Can you tell me a little
bit more about how you guys
were able to drive innovation in ways

that you might not have
otherwise been able to
due to the things you get from the cloud?

- Yes, the notion of a
single coordinated model

that is accessible to
everyone working on a project,
is it just drives so much productivity.

And I'll tell you, that's
because in the past,

people would have their own
copies of these things, right?

You'd have maybe three
firms working on something,
you'd have your copy, I'd have my copy.

How are we sure that we were
all working off of the same,
most up-to-date information?

How did we communicate?
That would be on like paper.
Still, even today.

So by centralizing all of
this, people are able to work
much more dynamically.

They're able to actually
build on each other's ideas

and collaborate in real time
by leveraging the cloud.

It also makes it easier to
onboard new stakeholders

and to leverage the data
throughout the whole design
through construction process.

And really it used to be
stacks and stacks and stacks

of drawings, and it
still is in some cases.
And things get built in the wrong place

and have to be torn up
because people aren't working
off the same coordinated information.

- So iteration and innovation,
is that at play also?

Does that help?
- It does.

- You have an acceleration?
- It does, because you know,

it's not just about putting
the data in the cloud.
It's, okay, now that it's here,
how do we make it more valuable?

- That's right, so overall,
Amy, if you think to the future,
you know, fast forward however many years

you wanna think about, are
there any words of wisdom
or advice that you'd give to other leaders
as they're contemplating all this?

- So when I think of the
future, the first word

that actually popped into
my head was uncertainty,

because I never could've
predicted the last two years.

But I think many of us
thrived through this period
of constant change in the last two years.
And for me, I think as leaders,
if we learn to embrace uncertainty,
but also help our employees, you know,
have empathy for the employees,
help them do their best work

while they're navigating
through the uncertainty,

and be open and take
risks in the right places,

I think, I mean, we're
accelerating so many things

that I don't think we
thought we were going to.

- So Amy, thank you so
much for your time today.

It's often a privilege to
be able to sit with people

like yourself who have such
accomplished organizations
and great successes, so it's great for us

to be able to celebrate
those successes with you.

Congratulations to the work
you guys have done at Autodesk.

And thanks so much for your
investment of time today.

- Well, thank you, too. I really
appreciate the opportunity.
